problems.title: Number of Factors
problems.question: How many factors does 180 have?
problems.hint: First find the prime factorization, then use formula (a+1)(b+1)(c+1)...

problems.title: Unit Digit of Power
problems.question: What is the unit digit of 3⁴⁷?
problems.solution:
Unit digit pattern of 3: 3→9→7→1→3 (cycle of 4)
47 mod 4 = 3
Third in cycle = 7
problems.hint: 3 has a cycle of 4 for unit digits. Find 47 mod 4.

problems.title: Trailing Zeros in Factorial
problems.question: How many trailing zeros are there in 125!?
problems.hint: Count factors of 5: ⌊n/5⌋ + ⌊n/25⌋ + ⌊n/125⌋...

problems.title: HCF and LCM Relationship
problems.question: The HCF of two numbers is 18 and their LCM is 3780. If one number is 270, find the other number.
problems.solution:
HCF × LCM = Product of two numbers
18 × 3780 = 270 × x
x = (18 × 3780) / 270 = 252
problems.hint: Use the property: HCF × LCM = Product of the two numbers

problems.title: Remainder with Large Power
problems.question: What is the remainder when 7¹⁰⁰ is divided by 13?
problems.solution:
By Fermat's Little Theorem: 7¹² ≡ 1 (mod 13)
100 = 12 × 8 + 4
7¹⁰⁰ = (7¹²)⁸ × 7⁴ ≡ 1 × 2401 ≡ 2401 mod 13
2401 = 184 × 13 + 9
Remainder = 9
problems.hint: Use Fermat's Little Theorem: aᵖ⁻¹ ≡ 1 (mod p) for prime p

problems.title: Perfect Square Factors
problems.question: How many factors of 1800 are perfect squares?
problems.solution:
1800 = 2³ × 3² × 5²
For perfect square factors, powers must be even.
2: can be 0 or 2 (2 choices)
3: can be 0 or 2 (2 choices)
5: can be 0 or 2 (2 choices)
Total = 2 × 2 × 2 = 8
problems.hint: Only even powers of primes give perfect squares. Count even power combinations.

problems.title: Basic Percentage Calculation
problems.question: If 35% of a number is 280, what is 55% of that number?
problems.hint: First find the original number, then calculate 55% of it.

problems.title: Successive Percentage Change
problems.question: A price increases by 20% and then decreases by 20%. What is the net percentage change?
problems.hint: Use formula: a + b + (ab/100) for successive percentage changes.

problems.title: Profit Percentage Calculation
problems.question: A shopkeeper marks goods 50% above cost price and gives 20% discount. What is the profit percentage?
problems.solution:
Let CP = 100
MP = 150 (50% above)
SP = 150 × 0.8 = 120 (20% discount)
Profit = 20, Profit% = 20%
problems.hint: Track: CP → MP (markup) → SP (discount). Profit% is always on CP.

problems.title: Two Articles Same Selling Price
problems.question: A man sells two items at Rs. 1980 each. On one he gains 10% and on other loses 10%. Find net profit or loss percentage.
problems.solution:
When two articles sold at same SP with x% profit on one and x% loss on other:
Net Loss% = x²/100 = 10²/100 = 1%
Alternatively: CP₁ = 1980/1.1 = 1800, CP₂ = 1980/0.9 = 2200
Total CP = 4000, Total SP = 3960, Loss = 40, Loss% = 1%
problems.hint: Use shortcut: When SP is same, loss% = x²/100

problems.title: Compound Percentage Change
problems.question: The population of a city increases by 10% in first year, decreases by 5% in second year, and increases by 15% in third year. If final population is 1,30,455, what was initial population?
problems.hint: Work backwards: Initial = Final / (1.1 × 0.95 × 1.15)

problems.title: Basic Speed Calculation
problems.question: A train covers 480 km in 8 hours. What is its speed in m/s?
problems.solution:
Speed = 480/8 = 60 km/hr
Converting to m/s: 60 × 5/18 = 50/3 ≈ 16.67 m/s
problems.hint: First find speed in km/hr, then convert using × 5/18 to get m/s.

problems.title: Average Speed Problem
problems.question: A person travels from A to B at 30 km/hr and returns at 50 km/hr. What is the average speed for the entire journey?
problems.solution:
For same distance, average speed = 2S₁S₂/(S₁+S₂)
= 2 × 30 × 50 / (30 + 50) = 3000/80 = 37.5 km/hr
problems.hint: Use harmonic mean formula for average speed when distance is same.

problems.title: Train Crossing Platform
problems.question: A 300m long train running at 90 km/hr crosses a platform in 36 seconds. Find the length of the platform.
problems.solution:
Speed = 90 km/hr = 90 × 5/18 = 25 m/s
Distance covered = 25 × 36 = 900m
Platform length = 900 - 300 = 600m
problems.hint: Total distance = Train length + Platform length. Use Speed × Time.

problems.title: Boats and Streams
problems.question: A boat travels 36 km downstream in 4 hours and returns in 6 hours. Find the speed of the stream.
problems.solution:
Downstream speed = 36/4 = 9 km/hr
Upstream speed = 36/6 = 6 km/hr
Stream speed = (9-6)/2 = 1.5 km/hr
problems.hint: Stream speed = (Downstream - Upstream)/2

problems.title: Relative Speed Meeting
problems.question: Two trains start from stations A and B towards each other. First train's speed is 60 km/hr, second's is 40 km/hr. When they meet, first train has traveled 120 km more than second. Find the distance between A and B.
problems.solution:
Let meeting time = t hours
Distance by first = 60t, by second = 40t
60t - 40t = 120
20t = 120, t = 6 hours
Total distance = 60(6) + 40(6) = 360 + 240 = 600 km
problems.hint: Difference in distance = Difference in speed × Time. Then find total.

problems.title: Basic Combined Work
problems.question: A can complete a work in 12 days, B in 18 days. Working together, they complete it in how many days?
problems.solution:
Combined time = (12 × 18)/(12 + 18) = 216/30 = 7.2 days
OR A's rate = 1/12, B's rate = 1/18
Combined rate = 1/12 + 1/18 = 5/36
Time = 36/5 = 7.2 days
problems.hint: Time = (A × B)/(A + B) for two workers.

problems.title: Pipes and Cisterns
problems.question: Pipe A fills a tank in 15 minutes, B empties it in 20 minutes. If both are opened, how long to fill the tank?
problems.solution:
A fills 1/15 per minute, B empties 1/20 per minute
Net filling rate = 1/15 - 1/20 = (4-3)/60 = 1/60 per minute
Time = 60 minutes
problems.hint: Inlet adds, outlet subtracts. Net rate = 1/15 - 1/20.

problems.title: Efficiency Ratio
problems.question: A is twice as efficient as B. Together they finish work in 6 days. How many days does A alone take?
problems.solution:
Let B's time = 2x days, A's time = x days (twice efficient means half time)
Together: x × 2x / (x + 2x) = 6
2x²/3x = 6
2x/3 = 6
x = 9 days
problems.hint: If A is twice efficient, A takes half the time B takes.

problems.title: Alternating Days Work
problems.question: A and B can complete work in 20 and 30 days respectively. They work on alternate days starting with A. On which day is work completed?
problems.solution:
Work = LCM(20,30) = 60 units
A = 3 units/day, B = 2 units/day
Two-day cycle: 5 units
12 cycles = 24 days = 60 units exactly
Work completes on 24th day
problems.hint: Use LCM method. Track 2-day cycles of work.

problems.title: Linear Seating Basic
problems.question: Five people A, B, C, D, E sit in a row facing north. A is at extreme right. C is immediate left of A. B is not adjacent to C. Who is in the middle?
problems.solution:
From right: _ _ _ C A
B not adjacent to C means B not in third position
Remaining: D and E in positions 1, 2 or B in 1 or 2
Multiple arrangements possible:
D B E C A or E B D C A or B E D C A, etc.
Middle position varies.
problems.hint: Draw the arrangement. Multiple valid arrangements may exist.

problems.title: Circular Seating
problems.question: 6 people sit in a circle facing center. A is opposite D. B is to immediate left of A. C is not adjacent to A or D. E is second to right of D. Who is adjacent to C?
problems.solution:
Fix A at 12 o'clock. D at 6 o'clock (opposite).
B immediate left of A means B at 11 o'clock.
E second right of D: D→next→E means E at 4 o'clock.
Remaining positions: 1 o'clock, 2 o'clock for C and F.
C not adjacent to A (rules out 1 o'clock) and not adjacent to D (2 o'clock is OK).
So C at 2 o'clock, F at 1 o'clock.
C's neighbors: E (at 4) and F (at 1) - wait, let me recheck positions.
Correct: C adjacent to E and F.
problems.hint: Fix one person, place others systematically. Remember facing center affects left/right.

problems.title: Percentage Growth
problems.question: Sales in 2020 were Rs. 450 crores. In 2021, sales increased by 12%. In 2022, sales increased by 15% over 2021. What were 2022 sales?
problems.hint: Apply percentage increases successively: multiply by 1.12, then by 1.15.

problems.title: Market Share Calculation
problems.question: Company A has 35% market share worth Rs. 420 crores. Company B has 25% share. What is B's sales in crores?
problems.solution:
Total market = 420/0.35 = 1200 crores
B's sales = 1200 × 0.25 = 300 crores
problems.hint: First find total market size from A's data, then calculate B's share.

problems.title: Main Idea Identification
problems.question: A passage discusses how social media has transformed political discourse, noting both increased citizen participation and the spread of misinformation. The main idea is:
options: Social media has complex effects on politics
Political discourse was better before social media
Misinformation is the biggest problem today
problems.correct_answer: Social media has complex effects on politics
problems.solution: The passage presents both positive (increased participation) and negative (misinformation) effects, indicating a balanced, complex view rather than a one-sided argument.
problems.hint: Look for the option that captures both aspects mentioned in the passage.

problems.title: Sentence Ordering with Pronouns
problems.question: Arrange: A. It is estimated to be 4.5 billion years old. B. The Earth is the third planet from the Sun. C. This age was determined using radiometric dating. D. Scientists continue to study its formation.
problems.solution:
B introduces Earth (no backward reference)
A gives detail about Earth ("It" refers to Earth)
C explains how age was determined ("This age" refers to previous sentence)
D continues about studying Earth
problems.hint: Look for pronoun references: 'It', 'This', to find the sequence.

problems.title: Find the Assumption
problems.question: Argument: 'Since employee satisfaction increased after implementing work-from-home policy, the policy should be continued.' The assumption is:
options: All employees prefer working from home
Employee satisfaction is the only metric that matters for policy decisions
The increase in satisfaction was caused by the policy
problems.correct_answer: The increase in satisfaction was caused by the policy
problems.solution: The argument assumes causation from correlation. The satisfaction increase could be due to other factors (e.g., salary raise, new projects) occurring at the same time.
problems.hint: What must be true for this conclusion to be valid? Look for the causal link assumption.

problems.title: Triangle Area
problems.question: A triangle has sides 13, 14, and 15. Find its area.
problems.hint: Use Heron's formula: Area = √[s(s-a)(s-b)(s-c)] where s is semi-perimeter.

problems.title: Quadratic Equation Roots
problems.question: If roots of x² - 7x + k = 0 are 3 and 4, find k.
problems.solution:
Sum of roots = 3 + 4 = 7 (matches -(-7)/1 = 7)
Product of roots = 3 × 4 = 12
So k = 12
problems.hint: Product of roots = c/a for ax² + bx + c = 0

problems.title: Permutations
problems.question: In how many ways can 6 people sit around a circular table?
problems.solution: Circular permutations = (n-1)! = (6-1)! = 5! = 120
problems.hint: For circular arrangements, use (n-1)! since rotations are same.

problems.title: Blood Relations
problems.question: A is father of B. B is not son of A. C is brother of B. D is mother of C. What is D to A?
problems.solution:
A is father of B. B is not son means B is daughter.
C is brother of B, so C is son of A.
D is mother of C (and B).
So D is wife of A.
problems.hint: B is not son of A but A is father, so B is daughter. Build family tree.

problems.title: Simple Interest Calculation
problems.question: Find simple interest on Rs. 5000 at 8% per annum for 3 years.
problems.hint: SI = (Principal × Rate × Time) / 100

problems.title: Compound Interest
problems.question: Find compound interest on Rs. 8000 at 10% p.a. for 2 years compounded annually.
problems.hint: Amount = P(1 + r/100)^n, CI = Amount - Principal
